title: How to Make Chicken Gravy

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a saucepan on the stove top over a medium heat.
steps.description: Measure ¼ cup (56 grams) of butter into the saucepan and wait for it to melt. If the butter starts to boil, turn down the heat. If you don’t have any butter, use margarine instead. Cut the butter into small pieces to make it melt quicker.

steps.headline: Stir the flour into the melted butter.
steps.description: Measure ⅓ cup (40 grams) of all-purpose flour into the melted butter. Mix the ingredients with a hand-held whisk until they are fully combined and the mixture has a paste consistency. If you don’t have a hand-held whisk, use a fork instead.

steps.headline: Whisk the chicken broth into the flour and butter until the mixture thickens.
steps.description: Add 2 cups (0.47 L) of chicken broth into the saucepan. Use a hand-held whisk to stir the ingredients into a smooth sauce. Keep stirring the gravy until it reaches your desired consistency. Purchase chicken broth from a supermarket. Use the back of a spoon to squish any lumps in the mixture. It typically takes about 10 minutes for the gravy to thicken.

steps.headline: Stir in the chicken drippings.
steps.description: Scrape 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of chicken drippings from the bottom of the roasting dish that you cooked the chicken in. This gives the gravy a delicious chicken flavour. Stir the mixture with a spoon until the drippings are evenly dispersed amongst the gravy.

steps.headline: Spoon the hot gravy over your roast chicken and vegetables.
steps.description: Gravy is a delicious way to add flavour to your roast meal. Use the gravy as a dipping sauce or spoon it over your meat and vegetables, and enjoy! Gravy tastes best hot; however, if you have some leftover, store it in the fridge for up to 2 days.

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a large saucepan on the stovetop.
steps.description: Measure ¼ cup (56 grams) of butter into the saucepan. Turn the heat up to medium and wait for the butter to melt. If the butter starts to boil or has a burning smell, turn down the heat. If you prefer not to use butter, use margarine instead.

steps.headline: Stir the flour into the butter for 10 minutes.
steps.description: This gives time for the mixture to turn a golden brown colour. Measure ½ cup (64 grams) of all-purpose flour into the butter, and then use a hand-held whisk to combine the ingredients. Continue to stir the mixture to stop it from sticking to the saucepan. Use a fork to mix the flour and butter, if you don’t have a hand-held whisk

steps.headline: Whisk the chicken stock into the flour and melted butter gradually.
steps.description: Slowly tip 4 cups (1 L) of chicken stock into the saucepan whilst you whisk the mixture. This helps to avoid lumps forming in the gravy. Purchase liquid stock from a cooking store or a supermarket. Choose a chicken stock that is made from real chicken to achieve the best taste.

steps.headline: Stir the mixture with a wooden spoon over a low heat for 10 minutes.
steps.description: This helps to thicken the gravy. Stir the mixture continuously to avoid the mixture burning on the bottom of the pan. Keep the mixture on the heat until it is thick enough to coat the rounded side of a spoon.

steps.headline: Mix in the cream, cayenne pepper, salt, and pepper into the gravy.
steps.description: Measure ⅓ cup (118 mL) of heavy cream, ¼ teaspoon (1.25 grams) of salt, ¼ teaspoon (0.5 grams) of pepper, and ¼ teaspoon (0.5 grams) of cayenne pepper into the gravy. Stir the mixture until the ingredients are combined. If the gravy is lacking flavour, stir another ¼ teaspoon (1.25 grams) of salt and ¼ teaspoon (0.5 grams) of pepper into the mixture.

steps.headline: Enjoy the delicious hot gravy with a roast meal.
steps.description: Pour the gravy over your meat and vegetable to add flavour to your meal. Chicken gravy tastes best hot served hot; however, if you have some leftover, store it in the fridge for up to 2 days.
